Award.AwardTitle: Understanding and Preventing Youth Crime: A Comparative Study in France, Germany, the Netherlands, the UK and the US

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Criminal offending, alcohol and drug use and victimization among teenagers remain pressing problems worldwide. A large number of different policies and programs targeting these youth problems exist and research supports the idea that such programs work best if they have a sound theoretical basis. While there are numerous theories focused on youth problems, recent thinking suggests there is a need for an integrated approach, combining individual, situational and macro-level theories. The first goal of the current study is to collect survey data on 3,600 7th, 8th and 9th graders in 4 US cities in order to develop and test such integrated theory.

At the same time, youth crime and victimization is a problem for many countries. Studying national and local youth policies and programs sheds light on why some countries have less serious youth-related problems than others. Therefore, the second goal of the study is to compare the experiences of American adolescents with those in the UK, France, Germany and The Netherlands to determine whether the same theories apply across countries, and to provide a comparative analysis of youth-related crime policies. Primary focus is on comparison between US, UK, Germany, France and The Netherlands, but analyses will also include 25 other countries which are part of the larger International Self-Report Delinquency (ISRD) study which collects self-administered surveys among random samples of 7th, 8th and 9th graders. All countries use the same research design, making results comparable. Information on youth policies will be collected through interviews with experts and open source documents. National data will be merged into an international data base for joint analysis and for the preparation of academic and policy papers, in the US and abroad.

In terms of broader impacts, the five "Understanding and Preventing Youth Crime" countries will assemble comprehensive information on the organisation of youth justice at the country-level in order to provide a comparative analysis of youth justice policies and structures, to set against the findings from the UPYC survey. The study will contribute to the development of an integrated theory of youth offending, and will trace the implications of this for youth justice policy. The project will have a broader impact by potentially improving youth policies which better the well-being of teenagers in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding why young people engage in offending and substance use, explaining where and why they are most vulnerable to crime, and gauging the effect the school and neighborhood environment has on the behavior of juveniles is at the core of many juvenile justice policies focusing on crime prevention among at-risk youth. In the increasingly globalized world, the answers to these questions often come from cross-national research that allows researchers to determine whether the experience of one country matches the experience of others and to assess the effectiveness of local juvenile justice policies by comparing them against the youth outcomes.

Our study responds to the demand for this knowledge by pursuing several goals. First, it charts international variations in youth offending and experience of crime as victims in home neighborhoods and at school. Second, it uses multiple theoretical explanations of criminal behavior to investigate the links between involvement in crime among students and their school and family socialization experiences, relationships with peers and family, and perceptions of safety in the neighborhoods of residence. Doing so allows us to assess the relative effectiveness of various explanations of criminal behavior and victimization in different societies. Third, it investigates differences and similarities in juvenile justice policies across countries, puts the study findings in the context of these policies, and draws out the implications of our findings for policies aiming to improve the lives of young people most at risk for criminal involvement and/or substance use.  

We accomplish all three of these goals by engaging in the UPYC project (Understanding and Preventing Youth Crime). The UPYC is a unique comparative survey of school children’s experiences of, and attitudes to, crime, victimization, and substance use, covering the United States, France, Germany, the Netherlands, and the UK.  The NSF-funded US study forms part of the International Self-Report Delinquency Study (ISRD), covering 35 countries. Although studies of juvenile delinquency and victimization conducted in single countries have been conducted in the past, our research study is the first to carry out multi-country comprehensive analyses of the connections between life experiences of students, their victimization and involvement in offending, and juvenile justice policies. The U.S. part of the study includes 2395 students residing in three large metro areas: Boston, Denver, and Miami.

The results of the study suggest that, relative to other Western countries, the US youth are particularly likely to encounter theft, cyber-bullying, and hate crime, are subject to more frequent physical punishment and maltreatment by parents; and are significantly less likely to report their victimization—assault, theft, and robbery—to police. Relative to the other four UPYC countries, the US youth taking part in the study appear to be more at risk for being involved in minor types of property and violent offending. At the same time, we find the risk factors for offending and substance use to be remarkably similar across countries: residence in disadvantaged communities, poor relationships with parents, significant amount of time spent outside of home with friends, and poor school performance are associated with deviant behavior in both the U.S. and other UPYC countries.

The study has a broad impact on the field of criminology as well as on the development of juvenile justice policies targeting crime prevention and rehabilitation of youth most at risk for offending and victimization. Informing U.S. juvenile justice policies, our findings highlight the crucial role of school environment in delinquency prevention, the importance of fostering a relationship between police and society, and the need to create the atmosphere of cultural inclusion on both school and societal levels. In the realm of science, the study contributes to a growing international database on youth delinquency and victimization and answers important questions about youth offending, victimization, and the relative effectiveness of theoretical explanations of crime and victimization across countries. It also contributes to a better understanding of the challenges of conducting standardized surveys across a broad range of countries.

The NSF grant was part of an Open Research Area (ORA plus 2013) collaborative funding effort by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO), UK Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC), German Research Foundation (DFG), the French National Research Agency (ANR), and NSF. The grant allowed each partner to participate in the ISRD project and, as a by-product, enabled us to steer the larger project toward a successful conclusion. The ISRD research network is now an important collaborative endeavor of researchers across the globe who seek to understand how national and local policies are related to youth crime and victimization. The ISRD has also become a significant source of international data, and it is expected to continue in 2020 with a new wave of data collection, building on the insights of juvenile justice experts across the globe. For more information see www.northeastern.edu/isrd/
